dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains core C programming concepts such as pointers, memory management, and control structures.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; illustrates pointers with visual memory diagrams; explains structs with concrete examples.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague explanations; jumps between topics like arrays and functions without clear transitions.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, energy, and engagement when teaching C syntax, compilation process, and debugging techniques.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear articulation of code snippets; varied tone when highlighting important keywords; steady pace that allows note‑taking.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone delivery; speaks too quickly through complex code; excessive filler words that obscure meaning.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of C lessons: introduction → concept explanation → coding example → live demonstration → summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with problem statement, explains the relevant C constructs, writes a complete program step‑by‑step, then reviews key takeaways.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Randomly switches between topics like file I/O and bitwise operators; no clear beginning or wrap‑up.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners through questions, hands‑on coding exercises, and real‑world C applications.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses probing questions about why a pointer needs dereferencing; encourages students to modify a sample program and observe results.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Delivers a one‑way lecture; never checks if students understand concepts like memory allocation or loop invariants.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of C language information, including syntax, standard library functions, and best practices.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Accurately describes the difference between `malloc` and `calloc`; uses correct function prototypes and data types.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: States that `sizeof(char)` is 2 bytes; misrepresents the behavior of `strcpy` leading to buffer overflow risks.
